text: I think one of the most exciting
phenomena has been um been elucidated
and really brought to the Forefront by
Dr Javier castalanos a Child and
Adolescent psychiatrist who years before
a decade ago was telling us that the
real action in the brain is while the
brain's at rest not while the brain is
doing stuff and so you have to
understand that when we were trying to
find we're looking for the bio marker
we're looking for the equivalent of a
blood test if you come into a doctor's
office and you're coughing and you have
a chest cold and the cold makes you feel
terrible we can do a blood test and tell
you whether or not it's a virus or if
it's bacterial if it's bacterial we give
you antibiotics if it's a virus we just
wait for the virus to die you will live
longer than the virus so we give you
stuff to make you feel better whether
it's Tylenol or it's aspirin it's plenty
of fluids but there's no to make it go
away we don't have that in Psychiatry
that's the Holy Grail what's the
biomarker and so very when the MRI came
in or the cat skan first but the uh MRI
became the new way to look at the brain
these neuroimaging tools and so first
came the structural MRI to look at um
how does the brain how is it built and
is it buil differently in people who
have a certain psychiatric illness
versus a normal versus someone with a
different kind of psychiatric illness
and while that gave us some hints um as
group differences it wasn't as specific
as the functional MRI which you can
actually take a look at your brain and
see how it works now originally we would
put kids or adults into this machine and
have them do a task so that if you were
had a social anxiety disorder and so me
seeing faces that you knew versus faces
that you didn't know should activate
different parts of your brain and it was
very hard to find a difference uh when
you when you showed these um these tasks
or made these tasks and so what happened
was Castellano said this is kind of like
the post office when the post office is
closed there's a lot of action going on
there that's when people are talking to
each other they're moving bags of mail
they're organizing themselves when the
window comes up to sell you the stamps
or to accept your mail there's really a
lot less action going on so he basically
said the brain is talking to itself all
the time when it's resting when it's
sleeping and we most likely can tell the
difference between the way the brain
speaks to itself when you have ADHD or
when you have depression or if you're
typical or normal patient or subject and
therefore he has been been able to find
a section of the brain where you can
actually see a difference uh that he
hypothesizes has to do with attention
and one with cognition and one with mood
and what he's trying to do by
collaborating with people all over the
world and getting uh data whether
someone has autism or children who have
ADHD is to really start building curves
so that when you take your child to the
pediatrician and they take a height and
a weight it's meaningless unless you can
put it on a curve so if your child has
always been very skinny and has always
been on the 25th percentile that gives
you reassurance that the child is moving
along if your child becomes very fat all
of a sudden is now on the 75th per off
the physician is worried as to how that
is different if we could produce curves
of what the trajectory would look like
for a child with autism or a child with
ADHD or depression when a a patient
would come into the office who seems
very inattentive seems impulsive by
history seems hyperactive and you're not
sure that if you were able to be able to
do a resting state of with a functional
MRI and the child doesn't come on that
curve of ADHD you might say well there's
another reason maybe it's parents are
fighting maybe it's a boring teacher
maybe there's endless reasons why
someone could be uh inattentive and
impulsive but if they have that history
and they have that
biological um marker that's more
evidence and gives more confidence to
the ability to make a diagnosis and the
earlier we are able to make these
diagnoses we certainly know considering
how
the plasticity of the brain we are quite
convinced that we'll get better
treatments and be able to let kids have
much better lives we have 15 million
children in the United States today that
have a psychiatric disorder the
overwhelming majority never get any help
and what usually happens to them is that
they drop out of school they get in
trouble with the law and they go to jail
there are 7,000 child psychiatrists
there are 3,000 individuals who identify
themselves as child psychologists so the
math doesn't work so unless we're able
to figure out a better way of diagnosis
with more confidence and are able to
teach pediatricians how to uh diagnose
and evaluate and possibly treat or nurse
practitioners or social workers to do
this in a more systematic way we will
continue to lose many many kids um to
the bad outcomes that happen when you
have these
disorders
